DAW Comparison.md.author: austenballard
DAW Comparison.md.message_content: This takes a bit of work but if you have O-C tendencies like I do, it's a few hours well spent. I made .vstpreset files for every plugin I use (and .adv preset files for stock devices) and organized them like so. I keep an 'Unused' folder in each subfolder so I can quickly access something I don't use regularly, but also keep my usual choices pared down and easy to find. Also I have a separate color grouping for 'favorites'. I've done a similar layout in the Logic plugin manager.

Bounce and Export Workflows.md.author: Adam Thein
Bounce and Export Workflows.md.message_content:
Ah I see - so the way to get around the delay compensation issue with Return tracks in Live is to disable the sends on the track you are printing to.

So you are routing the mix using a send to a Return Track, then on a new Audio Track you set the input to be that Return Track, right?  Then on the Audio Track you have set to monitor, be sure to click "Disable All Sends" and that should correct any Delay Comp issues.

Bounce and Export Workflows.md.author: Ross Fortune
Bounce and Export Workflows.md.message_content:
Tried your cascading system - it works!

With one issue, but it's workable. Sending to a return from a nested track ("drum rack" within =DRUMS= here) is slightly delayed and causes phase, but sending from the parent track =DRUMS= is fine. Means parallels will have to be done per track, using Audio Effect Racks, but that's pretty fine in most real life instances.

Just make sure he isn't selecting "master/groups/send" because then it'll take 6 hours to render.

Troubleshooting DAW Issues.md.message_content:
So I've been experiencing a very specific problem for the last year and I want to see if anyone has been dealing with this and found a fix:

I have a two monitor mac setup (top and bottom) and if I open a drop-down menu inside of a plugin (like a preset menu or an algorithm selection) it opens up the menu on my second monitor as it's own detached window, which means I have to then drag my mouse cursor up to the next monitor to click it.

Has anyone successfully fixed this issue?

Keyboard Shortcuts and Macros.md.author: Slow Hand
Keyboard Shortcuts and Macros.md.message_content:
I'll do something similar with an *Instrument Rack* when it comes to pitched samples like 808's.

I'll load a whole folder of 808s into individual chains. Then I use a *macro* knob to control *chain selection*. This allows me to route my MIDI data to a different chain and play the 808 sample on it.

As we all know, 808 samples can come in all types of different pitches (C, C#, F, Bb, etc). I'll spend the time to transpose/re-pitch each sample so that when I play *middle C* on a keyboard the 808

Computer Hardware for Audio.md.author: chadwahlbrink

Backup and Storage for Audio.md.author: Will Melones
Backup and Storage for Audio.md.message_content: Interesting update to this Finder thing. I had noticed that the Archive Utility settings were defaulted to "compressed archive" format and figured that was another format that ended in .zip, since we've all been using it this whole time. When I gave @sethearnest's technique a whirl (worked like a charm), the file created ended with .cpgz! Compressed archive, not a zip at all. Soooo apparently Archive Utility settings do change stuff, but that has nothing to do with the behavior of the right clic
